Award.AwardTitle: Boundaries of Random Walks and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "Boundaries of Random Walks and Applications" that will be held on June 4-6, 2019 at Bowdoin College.

The conference focuses on the topic of random walks on groups, which interfaces core areas of mathematical analysis and related fields, specifically probability, ergodic theory, geometry, and operator algebras. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at: https://sites.google.com/view/boundariesrw/home

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved hosting a three-day conference, entitled "Boundaries of Random Walks and Applications" on the campus of Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Maine. There had not been any similar conference directly related to the theory of boundaries of random walks on groups in the last four years on the east coast, which made the conference unique. The conference brought together experts in the theory of random walks and group actions.  The goal of the conference was to develop further the interaction between probability, ergodic theory, and geometry. In recent years there have been some deep results involving random walks and the boundary theory, which expanded the area by either providing solutions to some conjectures or inventing alternative tools. The conference provided a valuable venue and opportunity for further discussions in detail of these new improvements to reveal the insights behind the enigmatic and innovative paths, which led to the results.  Another major goal of the conference was to expose graduate students and junior researchers in the area to the latest developments and have the opportunity to interact with the leading experts in this research area. More precisely, there were 43 participants at the conference. Of these, 30 consisted of early career researchers or students (specifically, there were 16 postdocs or faculty within five years of their Ph.D., 13 graduate students, and one undergraduate student).
